content: I could have simplified solution more than i did.  but i do not find this on the easy level.  BFS could fail in slow langs imo w/ Large Maze.  Queues and stacks imo are at least medium.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: more adventure)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: nice puzzle... very interesting way to travel in this puzzle. i get a little scared when you decided to add the out-of-map travel... but just minimal changes of code needed to be added.... why Brodo didn't use the eagles?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Another fun BFS.  The outside travel and diagonal mountain restrictions keep it interesting.  I figured out a clever way to check for mountain passes.

V2 Changes:

• Allowing for moving outside of the provided map - Provided not blocked by mountains.
• Complete rework of the test cases:
    • 1-8: Single directions
    • 9-12: Two directions together in an "open" map
    • 13-16: Adjacent Brodo and Mount Boom
    • 17: All diagonal directions in a single map
    • 18: All directions in a single map
    • 19-21: Mountain movement restriction tests
    • 22-24: Travelling outside the map in all directions.
    • 25: Final test for all directions, mountain restriction and travelling outside the map
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

I like the puzzle. The part of being able to move outside the map is nice (and slightly tricky), same for the restriction regarding mountains when moving diagonally. In total not very difficult, though. Was able to solve it in less than 10 minutes in Perl (and no, I didn't peek at your solution; though I did afterwards and realized that I could have simplified my solution by using a border of spaces around the map; I did it differently).

Maybe you should make it clearer how to output the distance. You need to use "1 league" if the distance is one, "[[n]] leagues" if more than one. Otherwise the reader might think it should be literally "[[n]] league(s)" always.

Hello.... nice puzzle....just a question, is normal that the M and B are never on the border of the grid? i am thinking of a test case like this:

input
3 3
  M
 ^^
  B
output
4 leagues

if that is normal i think that rule must be written on Constraints section.

Goal
* I'm not sure what it means to "move diagonally between two mountains that are adjacent to each other". I suggest to add an example to the explanation. If my understanding is correct, the example may be something like this:

Brodo cannot move from P to Q, or vice versa, in the following map:
```
P^
^Q
```

* Please add the space character to Map Legend (describing it as e.g. accessible subject to the rules mentioned above).

Tags
* Why is "Flood fill" relevant here?

Cases
* In "Complex 2" (both the test and the validator), please remove some of the mountains to cover the "diagonally-adjacent mountains" rule more (basically removing the mountains at all the corners), e.g. the test may become https://pastebin.com/Wwukrg0f . And similar modification to the validator.

Thanks.

* Yes your understanding is correct, I left out an example to see if the text made sense on it's own, but added one now.

* Added space to the legend, unsure if it should be a constant or not but left as text.

* Not sure why flood fill is there tbh...

* Updated both complex 2 cases - I'm also going to alter the large test to include more instances of diagonals as well as before submitting.

Thanks, as always!

Thanks!

In general, my idea was the border mountains is sort of the end of the world / map but I could add some tests like your example as 'zoomed in maps'. But I think with a slightly different output.

With your example it makes more sense to go SE->SW around the mountain (out of the grid) with a distance of 2 leagues. So I'm going to add a few cases like that and will have to update the statement accordingly.

Thanks!

I could but I think with the example, the user can infer the correct meaning. I'll leave it as it is for now, if others agree with you, then I will change it.

I agree the large maze was considerably larger than the others - so have reduced it.

In terms of difficulty ofc it's subjective but looking at others with BFS tag, and similar, they're classified as medium. I'm not sure if changing it after published breaks anything however...

I personally think all BFS puzzles should be categorised as at least Medium difficulty. The Easy category seems more appropriate for straightforward tasks involving basic string manipulation, conditionals, loops, and similar concepts. That said, since some BFS puzzles have already been placed under Easy, I'm not insisting on reclassifying them.

@Harry.B., it's ok to change the difficulty to Medium without breaking anything. The difficulty part of the url to a puzzle is just a filler and can be changed to anything, e.g. the following url works:

https://www.codingame.com/training/insanely_difficult/road-to-mount-boom

As for the current puzzle, @PatrickMcGinnisII, did you use PHP for your solution? I solved it in Python before @Harry.B. simplified the large maze case, and even then, I didn't find it particularly challenging. One trick I used, which I often rely on in other puzzles too, was precomputing the neighbours. I went straight down that path so I don't know whether it helped the code performance or not. But that might be worth trying if you haven't already.

Given example like: https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/sky-maze-adventures-1 which is just a standard BFS being a medium yet this has extra steps, easy doesn't really make sense. So will upgrade to medium - Especially since the success rate has been ~50% so far.

- The grid probably was fine but considering the rest are <50 and then the large maze was more than 800, was a bit of a jump.

Well a simple flood fill expanding the borders of the maze would do just fine.  But I used a minqueue using the dist+est.dist as the priority.  I did it in php, dunno about maze changes - i assume before.  When i tried storing the actual path as it searched it timed out, too many copies.  looks like maze is different now, 2 otherss have done it in php as well now.  bfs stack and queue methods both work now.  I counted how many steps and how many elements left in queue.  In order to make large maze validator work...i swapped the start and dest so it started more internally and that solved the original validator timeout.  Now i guess the maze is changed...any/all simple searches will work.  I guess the next level would be that Brodo's dwarf friend could tunnel thru 1 mountain. ha.

For your information:
* Flood fill - what I did was just adding a row on every side.
* Priority - I didn't use any.
* Storing actual path - I used the simplest BFS so I didn't have to store paths. I stored in a set which cells I had seen before. My BFS queue consisted of (current location, number of steps taken so far).
"Units" should be changed to "unit". After that, I suggest changing {{league(s)}} to {{league}}({{s}}) to keeping "s" as a separate, optional suffix and exclude brackets from the constant formatting.
is to travel outside the grid a good idea? i see from test number 43 that this puzzle gets a little exotic :)

Can't see why not... If there are no mountains blocking Brodo's path, he can go where he wants...

Imagine standing at the end of a mountain range that is 1000 leagues long, you can either go 2 leagues around it or the super long way around it... 
E.g.
B
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^...
M
Just need to think outside the box... or grid... or map... whatever you want to call it ;)
